fact: Peru has over 3,000 types of potatoes, many of which are only grown in the Andes.
The Andean condor, a symbol of the Andes, can fly to heights over 5,000 meters.
Machu Picchu was rediscovered in 1911 by explorer Hiram Bingham.
Lake Titicaca is the highest navigable lake in the world, sitting at over 3,800 meters above sea level.
Quechua was the official language of the Inca Empire and is still spoken by millions of people in Peru.
Peru is home to the ancient Caral civilization, one of the oldest in the world, over 5,000 years old.
Peruvian cuisine is recognized as one of the best in the world, with ceviche being the flagship dish.
In Peru, over 3,000 traditional festivals are celebrated annually, many with pre-Columbian roots.
The Amazon River originates in Peru, in the Arequipa region, and is the most water-rich river on the planet.
Vinicunca, the Rainbow Mountain, gets its colors from the mineral composition of the soil.
The Sechura Desert in Peru is one of the largest in South America and is home to unique oases like Huacachina.
The Nazca Lines, still surrounded by mystery, can only be fully appreciated from the air.
The Inti Raymi, or Festival of the Sun, is an Inca celebration still held every June in Cusco.
Peru has more than 1,800 species of birds, making it a paradise for birdwatching.
Native Peruvian cacao is among the finest in the world and is the base for internationally acclaimed gourmet chocolates.
